Freedom Through Faith

05/03/2013

The war in Sri Lanka may be over, but government injustice towards minority groups continues. Ruki Fernando talks to Fliss Turner about life beyond the headlines.

Image by

By undefined undefined

September 2008, the UN decides to flee Sri Lanka; the violence, the terrorism and the unequivocal pain which can no longer be avoided. Beyond its preliminary fences many civilians, young and old, scrabble and desperately plea for them to remain; to allow them the final vestiges of protection. As grubby hands reach through bars framing the UN building, eyes wide with fear and despondency peer through as many try to grapple with the fraying seams of safety for the Tamil community. It is apparent that these are the people trapped by an unmerciful government and rebels. The UN has however already made its decision. In convoy they leave. In the falling dust stands a country in desolation, awaiting the government's inevitable blow. At the height of Sri Lanka's Civil War neither news reporter nor headline could convey the sheer amount of pain felt by the small country off the coast of India. It is through talking to Ruki Fernando, human rights activist that I begin to look beyond the articles I've read and the documentaries I have seen. I can begin to distinguish the brutal anguish felt not by a country defined and diminished by fatality statistics, but its very people, the children, the families. Here I discovered the torment felt by Sri Lanka's people, generalised by the term "civilian" and diminished by the Civil War's atrocities. Ruki Fernando has been involved in human rights activism since 1997 and his work has been propelled by his work with the church and other secular groups. Education in human rights has been at the heart of his courageous work within the Sri Lankan communities and it is through this that I begin to discover the realities of righting power with knowledge, violence with resolution. He has been at the frontlines of the violence and it is with unprecedented clarity that he tells of the horrors of Sri Lanka's Civil War "Hundreds and perhaps even thousands of Tamils were being killed, injured almost every day. Most of it was by government military... the LTTE (rebel group claiming to fight for liberation of Tamils) also actively prevented people from leaving the war zone, even shooting at those trying to escape, forcibly recruited adults and children and tolerated no criticism." Beyond Sri Lanka's beautiful landscape, fabulous cultural facade, scars had begun to show. No matter how much the government tried to conceal its actions to the public eye the surface was beginning to crack. Travel became restricted, roads were closed and embargo was imposed upon food and medical supplies. Those, whose spirit had not been shattered attempted escape, fled the black cloud of violent oppression that had come to define their everyday lives.
"My difficulty has been to talk to good Christians and Buddhists who don't believe in equal rights and dignity."
Ruki speaks of these people with such concise honesty and the impossible situation they face in their quest for freedom. "All Tamils who managed to escape the war zone were detained illegally behind barbed wire, in inhumane conditions by the government." The Tamil community faced the inevitable violent, moral and physical disparagement. "The community lived in fear - there were frequent round ups and any Tamil could be arrested and detained at whim and fancy of police and military, sometimes for many years. Almost everyone detained would be tortured. There were also widespread abductions and political killings." Amongst the civilians killed, disappeared, arrested, detained and subjected to torture are lawyers, journalists, Catholic priests and human rights activists. Absolutely no one with a heart and mind is safe from abduction, murder, torture or attack and absolutely "no one has been prosecuted or convicted for these crimes." As the government moved in on the community, families fell to the cloying mud of dug trenches offering minimal protection, crawling through the dirt as children sobbed and parents prayed "Please God, save all these children." Many would not be saved. Despite Ruki speaking with light optimism of the country today, "Now there is no shelling, bombing, suicide bombers..." sanity has not been restored. "Although less in number, arrests and detention of Tamils, abductions killings still happen. Government critiques still live in fear." Regardless of the war officially coming to a close in May 2009, hope has since been no more than a notion of hypocrisy humoured by a government of violence and brutality. "There are also new forms of repression and domination of the minority Tamil community. The Government is banning commemorations, religious events and grieving for those dead and disappeared, the whole of North is heavily militarized with military playing the dominant role over civilian administration, and getting involved in education, running shops, restaurants and resorts". Families of the dead, the tortured, and the persecuted cannot grieve. The cemeteries of Tamil militants have been bulldozed, flattened into the soil, denying parents and loved ones the space to lay a flower, light a canfle and say a prayer. In their place stands "monuments glorifying the military, responsible for killing, injuring, disappearing, torture of tens of thousands of local people." Despite international law stating that hospitals are areas of protection, the injured and maimed could not seek solitude. Government militancy attacked, disregarding the red crosses atop makeshift infirmaries, whose roofs bore the final fragment of protection to a desperately vulnerable community. Along the rifting torrent of mud and rubble ran the blood of victims who had clung to the hope of safety below these red crosses which proffered their protection. Limbs scattered the vicinity, faces blown into distortion. And so I shall admit, it is this which is at the heart of which renders me aghast; the casual flippancy and humour which litters basic human morality. The internet is sprawling with documentaries and footage which belittles the 7000 miles which span the distance from our modest island. This life is a million miles away from our first world predicaments. Such footage portrays women, naked, abused, vulnerable, and loaded into trucks, piled up like chunks of meat, by government militia who coldly laugh and joke. These women have families, these sparks of hope and love in turmoil of misery, will never enlighten their darkness.
